author: sky.cactus
content: Sadly, I think Ethermine is big enough that if they don't fix that we likely won't see gas prices drop to single digits.  üò¢

author: sky.cactus
content: This is the nature of the free market though, if Ethermine wants to leave money on the table we can't stop them.  All we can do is encourage hashing power to move to mining pools that aren't leaving money on the table.

author: charleshe3782
content:
Hi, 

My name is Charles He.

I have a Phd in economics, know some game theory, computer sci, worked for tech companies, etc. 

Right now I‚Äôm writing an ‚Äúarticle‚Äù or blog post that is skeptical of crypto and blockchain. 

I‚Äôm not that important, but some important or thoughtful people might read it. 

I‚Äôve got a summary or outline below.

I‚Äôm here because I wanted to check if there anything substantially wrong, mischaracterized or omitted with the points below. 

I could be wrong and I‚Äôm genuinely trying to check my opinions and ‚Äúgive crypto and blockchain a fair shake‚Äù, but to be clear, the article may still turn out highly negatively.

author: charleshe3782
content:
**Liberatarian or ‚ÄúCypherpunk‚Äù Value of Crypto is Limited**

A major facet that motivates crypto is creating alternative currency or information structures that can protect individuals from the flaws of existing institutions, e.g. current governments, ‚Äúfiat‚Äù currency, etc. 

I‚Äôm uncertain, but I think it‚Äôs useful to just lump the entirety of these motivations into the philosophy of ‚ÄúCypherpunk‚Äù, which is a genuine, coherent and principled movement. 

However, the usefulness of crypto to Cypherpunk (or Cypherpunk as a whole) seems limited:

‚Äî It seems clear that the main or popular adherents to crypto do not genuinely believe in Cypherpunk. Instead, by far, speculation and standard entrepreneurship are the main drivers of activity in the crypto space.

‚Äî Importantly, the claims of crypto proponents that anonymous transactions and storage of money are useful in societal change seems highly implausible.

For example, there are narratives that say, disenfranchised women in Afghanistan could be economically liberated by Bitcoin. However, such a person still requires physical freedom and free access to other services (such as the internet). Otherwise, her property, including crypto keys, can be seized like any other property. The societal barriers that would prevent her from holding or using money meaningfully seem unaffected, regardless if she has a large amount of cryptocurrency. These issues seem like they could only be solved by institutional or societal change, which seems genuinely difficult.

Similarly, the ideas or narratives that cryptocurrency will enable cab drivers to work independent from services like ‚ÄúUber‚Äù or provide financial freedom to mathematicians seem implausible. These claims and their worldviews seem to ignore the key role that organizations and systems of control and governance play in organizing economic activity, and grossly overweight the value of being able to transact small amounts of money.

author: charleshe3782
content: ‚Äî In 2021, as crypto grows beyond a niche market, it‚Äôs not clear it resists the forces of institutions, money or governmental power that it typically claims to oppose. For example, mining and therefore control of the Bitcoin network is concentrated in a single, non-western country. In the US and western countries, if crypto currencies become wholeheartedly accepted, regulations and ‚ÄúKYC‚Äù seem likely to be fully inserted into crypto with implications for control and governance. A major, new trendy currency, Chia seems to have an entirely conventional business plan, with copyright enforcement, KYC and 1099 for pools and miners. In ETH, the highest quality community, control or power is concentrated in the hands of a few dozen developers. These people can and have edited the ETH blockchain to seize assets (to recover from a theft) and it is widely understood they effectively control development of functionality as well as ‚Äúmonetary‚Äù policy over the currency.
